annotation.TEXT: This is the other thing that makes this game quite lengthy: There are 10 Robot Masters instead of the usual 8. While their levels may have the same tilesets from their original games, all of the paths are pretty much custom built from the ground up. So while you may see some familiar themes in each stage, don't expect to see much, if any of the original layouts here.

Well then...despite his appearance, the Mechazaurus has always been about as threatening as an intro-stage boss, so this seems like a good place for him. The only real change to this fight are the spikes on the upper left of the ceiling (which I honestly didn't even notice during my first time fighting him). Even with this, he's still not that much of a threat.

The game itself isn't hard to install or record or anything like that, but rather, my preparation is mainly due to this game's length. This is easily going to be the longest Mega Man related game I've done a playthrough on so far. Yes, even longer than Mega Man Revolution (hence why I had to skip the game's intro to save time). Planning an optimal route for this game isn't easy in the slightest, especially if you want to find a majority of what it has to offer.

Toad Man has been modified quite a bit in comparison to his original version. He now hops around on his own accord and can fire small shots towards you. He also has a desperation move where he jumps into the waterfall before popping up periodically to shoot at you. Despite all of this (and the water current in his boss room), this fight is still relatively easy.

So then, time to finally tackle this game. This one has definitely been long overdue, but better late than never. "Mega Man: Revenge of the Fallen" is a fan-game I've been meaning to get around to for a while now, though it definitely required a decent amount of preparation on my part before going through with it.

As mentioned before, I only came here to get Rush Coil for the most part, but Rain Flush isn't too bad either. It still functions the same way as the original, although its total ammo count did get bumped down slightly (it has 6 uses here as oppossed to its original 7).

For the record, that was actually a mini E-Tank back there. They show up in several alternate paths in almost every stage, along with W and M-Tank variations. Collect enough of them, and you'll earn yourself a full Tank.

Knock back is a little bit strange at times. As seen there, Mega Man can sometimes change directions during it. I'm not sure what exactly causes this, but I think it might depend on how you're hit and whether or not you're holding a direction when you collide with something.

That opening to the left was actually from a different path (albeit one you wouldn't be able to access at this point in the game). Every stage has different paths you can take, although most of these alternate routes (or at least, the ones that lead to unique items) require certain weapons to get through however.

Every stage has some form of unique hidden item within them. Some of them are Rush-related abilities, while others grant you small upgrades. The Rush Coil in particular is the main reason I wanted to do Toad Man's stage first, since it's pretty much essential to reach certain alternate paths in most of the other levels.

Wasting no time, let's dive right into the basics: Mega Man himself functions like he does from MM4 and onward. The slide is relatively fine, but the buster is a bit...strange. Aside from having a weird choice in sound effects (both in charging up and firing), it takes a bit longer than usual to build up a fully charged buster shot.

This is the only really tricky thing about this fight. You have to avoid these bullets while staying away from the waterfall. If you walk anywhere near it, Toad Man will pop out, grab you, drag you inside, and will then proceed to eat you (okay, not really - but he does drain your health if he gets you).
